The behaviors of an intrinsic toroidal rotation without any external momentum sources are investigated in KSTAR. In these experiments, pure ohmic discharges with a wide range of plasma parameters a...
meta.name: twitter:description

meta.content: The behaviors of an intrinsic toroidal rotation without any external momentum sources are investigated in KSTAR. In these experiments, pure ohmic discharges with a wide range of plasma parameters are carefully selected and analyzed to speculate an unrevealed origin of toroidal rotation excluding any unnecessary heating sources, magnetic perturbations, and strong magneto-hydrodynamic activities. The measured core toroidal rotation in KSTAR is mostly in the counter-current direction and its magnitude strongly depends on the ion temperature divided by plasma current (Ti/IP). Especially the core toroidal rotation in the steady-state is well fitted by Ti/IP scaling with a slope of ∼−23, and the possible explanation of the scaling is compared with various candidates. As a result, the calculated offset rotation could not explain the measured core toroidal rotation since KSTAR has an extremely low intrinsic error field. For the stability conditions for ion and electron turbulences, it is hard to determine a dominant turbulence mode in this study. In addition, the intrinsic toroidal rotation level in ITER is estimated based on the KSTAR scaling since the intrinsic rotation plays an important role in stabilizing resistive wall modes for future reference.

div.div:
The behaviors of an intrinsic toroidal rotation without any external momentum sources are investigated in KSTAR. In these experiments, pure ohmic discharges with a wide range of plasma parameters are carefully selected and analyzed to speculate an unrevealed origin of toroidal rotation excluding any unnecessary heating sources, magnetic perturbations, and strong magneto-hydrodynamic activities. The measured core toroidal rotation in KSTAR is mostly in the counter-current direction and its magnitude strongly depends on the ion temperature divided by plasma current (T
i
/I
P
). Especially the core toroidal rotation in the steady-state is well fitted by T
i
/I
P
scaling with a slope of ∼−23, and the possible explanation of the scaling is compared with various candidates. As a result, the calculated offset rotation could not explain the measured core toroidal rotation since KSTAR has an extremely low intrinsic error field. For the stability conditions for ion and electron turbulences, it is hard to determine a dominant turbulence mode in this study. In addition, the intrinsic toroidal rotation level in ITER is estimated based on the KSTAR scaling since the intrinsic rotation plays an important role in stabilizing resistive wall modes for future reference.
I. INTRODUCTION
Section:

The toroidal rotation in magnetic confinement fusion experiments has long been investigated since it is essential for plasma stabilities,
1–4
1. A. M. Garofalo, E. J. Strait, L. C. Johnson, R. J. La Haye, E. A. Lazarus, G. A. Navratil, M. Okabayashi, J. T. Scoville, T. S. Taylor, and A. D. Turnbull, Phys. Rev. Lett.
89
(23), 235001 (2002).
https://doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevLett.89.235001
2. A. Bondeson and D. J. Ward, Phys. Rev. Lett.
72
(17), 2709–
2712
(1994).
https://doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevLett.72.2709
3. E. J. Strait, T. S. Taylor, A. D. Turnbull, J. R. Ferron, L. L. Lao, B. Rice, O. Sauter, S. J. Thompson, and D. Wróblewski, Phys. Rev. Lett.
74
(13), 2483–
2486
(1995).
https://doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevLett.74.2483
4. I. T. Chapman, J. P. Graves, C. Wahlberg, and MAST Team, Nucl. Fusion
50
(2), 025018 (2010).
https://doi.org/10.1088/0029-5515/50/2/025018
and the rotation shear plays an important role in improving plasma confinement by suppressing turbulent transport.
5,6
5. T. S. Hahm and K. H. Burrell, Phys. Plasmas
2
(5), 1648–
1651
(1995).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.871313
6. K. H. Burrell, Phys. Plasmas
4
(5), 1499–
1518
(1997).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.872367
The toroidal rotation generated by the neutral beam injection (NBI) is expected to be small in a large-size fusion device such as ITER because of a large moment of inertia. Therefore, the intrinsic rotation without any external torque is considered as an additional source of the toroidal rotation, and its scaling has been highly focused since a faster toroidal rotation is more beneficial to suppress RWM (resistive wall modes) which makes plasma vulnerable to disruptions.

With an exception of direct torque source such as NBI, most toroidal rotation changes accompanied with confinement transitions, external heating and magnetic perturbation (MP) have been known in wide ranges of intrinsic rotation studies.
7
7. J. E. Rice, Plasma Phys. Controlled Fusion
58
(8), 083001 (2016).
https://doi.org/10.1088/0741-3335/58/8/083001
In the case of MP, toroidal rotation changes are caused by strong electromagnetic forces
8,9
8. M. F. F. Nave and J. A. Wesson, Nucl. Fusion
30
(12), 2575 (1990).
https://doi.org/10.1088/0029-5515/30/12/011
9. M. Okabayashi, P. Zanca, E. J. Strait, A. M. Garofalo, J. M. Hanson, Y. In, R. J. L. Haye, L. Marrelli, P. Martin, R. Paccagnella, C. Paz-Soldan, P. Piovesan, C. Piron, L. Piron, D. Shiraki, F. A. Volpe, and DIII-D and R.FX–Mod Teams, Nucl. Fusion
57
(1), 016035 (2017).
https://doi.org/10.1088/1741-4326/57/1/016035
and neoclassical toroidal viscosity (NTV).
10
10. A. M. Garofalo, A. D. Turnbull, M. E. Austin, J. Bialek, M. S. Chu, K. J. Comer, E. D. Fredrickson, R. J. Groebner, R. J. La Haye, L. L. Lao, E. A. Lazarus, G. A. Navratil, T. H. Osborne, B. W. Rice, S. A. Sabbagh, J. T. Scoville, E. J. Strait, and T. S. Taylor, Phys. Rev. Lett.
82
(19), 3811–
3814
(1999).
https://doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevLett.82.3811
In radio-frequency wave heated plasmas, a fast ion transport
11
11. L. G. Eriksson, T. Hellsten, M. F. F. Nave, J. Brzozowski, K. Holmström, T. Johnson, J. Ongena, K. D. Zastrow, and J.-E. Contributors, Plasma Phys. Controlled Fusion
51
(4), 044008 (2009).
https://doi.org/10.1088/0741-3335/51/4/044008
and NTV induced by strong magneto-hydrodynamic (MHD) activity
12
12. J. Seol, S. G. Lee, B. H. Park, H. H. Lee, L. Terzolo, K. C. Shaing, K. I. You, G. S. Yun, C. C. Kim, K. D. Lee, W. H. Ko, J. G. Kwak, W. C. Kim, Y. K. Oh, J. Y. Kim, S. S. Kim, and K. Ida, Phys. Rev. Lett.
109
(19), 195003 (2012).
https://doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevLett.109.195003
also change the toroidal rotation. To minimize these effects in our intrinsic rotation studies, we selected all experimental data within qualified ohmic L-mode plasmas without strong MHD activities except sawtooth crashes. Furthermore, we focused on qualitative scaling studies from experimental data since the origin of ohmic toroidal rotation has not been clearly understood yet.

The relationship between intrinsic rotation and plasma parameter has been investigated through a scaling approach and a typical example is known as the Rice scaling.
13
13. J. E. Rice, A. Ince-Cushman, J. S. deGrassie, L. G. Eriksson, Y. Sakamoto, A. Scarabosio, A. Bortolon, K. H. Burrell, B. P. Duval, C. Fenzi-Bonizec, M. J. Greenwald, R. J. Groebner, G. T. Hoang, Y. Koide, E. S. Marmar, A. Pochelon, and Y. Podpaly, Nucl. Fusion
47
(11), 1618 (2007).
https://doi.org/10.1088/0029-5515/47/11/025
Since it usually scales with ΔW
T
/I
P
during the confinement transition, this shows a strong linear relationship between the change of the toroidal rotation in the co-current direction and the increment of a stored energy (ΔW
T
). This scaling has been applied with a toroidal rotation database in many tokamak devices and showed consistent results. Recently, Parra
et al.
produced another scaling in counter-current rotating plasmas and it scales with T
i
/I
P
based on the theoretical arguments.
14
14. F. I. Parra, M. F. F. Nave, A. A. Schekochihin, C. Giroud, J. S. de Grassie, J. H. F. Severo, P. de Vries, and K. D. Zastrow, Phys. Rev. Lett.
108
(9), 095001 (2012).
https://doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevLett.108.095001
Although a relative rotation between the core and edge is utilized to compensate the edge rotation effect in Ref.
14
14. F. I. Parra, M. F. F. Nave, A. A. Schekochihin, C. Giroud, J. S. de Grassie, J. H. F. Severo, P. de Vries, and K. D. Zastrow, Phys. Rev. Lett.
108
(9), 095001 (2012).
https://doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevLett.108.095001
, it is fully considered as a core intrinsic rotation scaling for the plasmas with a counter-current direction. This T
i
/I
P
dependence on the core intrinsic rotation has been observed both theoretically and experimentally in spite of various formation mechanisms.
14–16
14. F. I. Parra, M. F. F. Nave, A. A. Schekochihin, C. Giroud, J. S. de Grassie, J. H. F. Severo, P. de Vries, and K. D. Zastrow, Phys. Rev. Lett.
108
(9), 095001 (2012).
https://doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevLett.108.095001
15. K. Ida, Y. Miura, K. Itoh, S. Itoh, I. ndash, and T. Matsuda, J. Phys. Soc. Jpn.
67
(12), 4089–
4097
(1998).
https://doi.org/10.1143/JPSJ.67.4089
16. A. Scarabosio, A. Bortolon, B. P. Duval, A. Karpushov, and A. Pochelon, Plasma Phys. Controlled Fusion
48
(5), 663 (2006).
https://doi.org/10.1088/0741-3335/48/5/012
Edge intrinsic rotation velocity also depends on T
i
/I
P
scaling due to edge thermal ion orbit losses,
17–19
17. J. S. deGrassie, R. J. Groebner, K. H. Burrell, and W. M. Solomon, Nucl. Fusion
49
(8), 085020 (2009).
https://doi.org/10.1088/0029-5515/49/8/085020
18. W. M. Solomon, K. H. Burrell, J. S. deGrassie, J. A. Boedo, A. M. Garofalo, R. A. Moyer, S. H. Muller, C. C. Petty, and H. Reimerdes, Nucl. Fusion
51
(7), 073010 (2011).
https://doi.org/10.1088/0029-5515/51/7/073010
19. J. S. deGrassie, J. A. Boedo, and B. A. Grierson, Phys. Plasmas
22
(8), 080701 (2015).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.4928558
strong NTV,
20
20. A. J. Cole, C. C. Hegna, and J. D. Callen, Phys. Plasmas
15
(5), 056102 (2008).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.2838241
or momentum imbalance.
21
21. T. Stoltzfus-Dueck, Phys. Rev. Lett.
108
(6), 065002 (2012).
https://doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevLett.108.065002

In this paper, the experimental data from KSTAR are directly compared with the existing scaling laws and investigated with various theoretical hypotheses. Since the KSTAR intrinsic error field is observed to be extremely small
22
22. Y. In, J. K. Park, J. M. Jeon, J. Kim, and M. Okabayashi, Nucl. Fusion
55
(4), 043004 (2015).
https://doi.org/10.1088/0029-5515/55/4/043004
and the experimental data are selected within carefully qualified pure ohmic discharges, the scaling results can be considered as the closest level of the natural rotation. Besides, we can predict the intrinsic rotation level in ITER with the KTSAR scaling result and provide the experimental background of the rotation control.
II. CALIBRATIONS FOR XICS MEASUREMENTS
Section:

The X-ray imaging crystal spectrometer (XICS)
23
23. S. Lee, J. Bak, U. Nam, M. Moon, Y. Shi, M. Bitter, and K. Hill, Rev. Sci. Instrum.
81
(10), 10E506 (2010).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.3478631
and charge exchange recombination spectroscopy (CES)
24
24. W.-H. Ko, H. Lee, D. Seo, and M. Kwon, Rev. Sci. Instrum.
81
(10), 10D740 (2010).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.3496991
have been utilized as the main diagnostics for toroidal rotation studies in tokamak plasmas. Especially, the XICS can be applied for temporal behaviors of toroidal rotation measurements even including the plasma current ramp-up period as long as an early Ar gas puffing is injected. The XICS measurement in KSTAR usually provides a relative toroidal rotation so that a careful calibration with various different methods is needed. Fortunately, KSTAR equips both XICS and CES, which measure argon and carbon impurities, respectively. Simultaneous core toroidal rotation and ion temperature measurements of different impurities species from the XICS and CES have shown reasonable agreement with various plasma discharges in KSTAR including ohmic plasmas.
25
25. S. G. Lee, H. H. Lee, W. H. Ko, and J. W. Woo, Fusion Sci. Technol.
69
(2), 555–
559
(2016).
https://doi.org/10.13182/FST15-174
For the calibration of the absolute value of the toroidal rotation, the time evolution of the rotation measurements are compared with the poloidal/toroidal mode number m/n = 1/1 MHD instability frequency. A typical example of the m/n = 1/1 MHD mode is the sawtooth precursor and it generally does not move in the plasma frame. A mode-locking phenomenon is also used to calibrate XICS measurements. When the external resonant magnetic perturbation (RMP) triggers a mode-locking, the toroidal rotation damps to zero by the electromagnetic forces in the opposite direction of the toroidal rotation. In this experiment, the core rotation is carefully calibrated with a clear sawtooth precursor and/or RMP induced mode-locking without strong MHD instabilities in every discharge.
III. TIME EVOLUTIONS AND PROFILES OF ROTATION IN OHMIC PLASMAS
Section:

The time evolution of toroidal rotation and ion/electron temperature in ohmic discharge is shown in Fig.
1
. The plasma current is 400 kA with a limited circular plasma shape (elongation is about 1.2). The (−) sign of the toroidal rotation (V
ϕ
) means a counter-current direction. Due to the early measurement, an inflection point is observed during the plasma current ramp-up phase. It represents that the plasma is affected by a strong counter torque at the beginning of the discharge and the direction of the net torque on the plasma is changed at the plasma current of about 300 kA in the most of 400 kA targeted plasmas. After passing the inflection point, the plasma accelerates in the co-current direction and finally a level of the toroidal rotation is saturated during the plasma current flat top phase unless there are drastic plasma changes. Although the averaged electron density gradually increases beyond the saturated density (n
S
) of about 2.1 × 10
19
m
−3
at 2.2 s, the core toroidal rotation and ion temperature are almost constant except the electron temperature. Here, n
S
is the plasma density at an ohmic energy confinement saturation.
26
26. J. Wesson and D. J. Campbell,
Tokamaks
(
Clarendon Press
, 2004).
A toroidal rotation reversal with the plasma density increments has been frequently observed near n
S
for many devices.
27,28
27. C. Angioni, R. M. McDermott, F. J. Casson, E. Fable, A. Bottino, R. Dux, R. Fischer, Y. Podoba, T. Pütterich, F. Ryter, and E. Viezzer, Phys. Rev. Lett.
107
(21), 215003 (2011).
https://doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevLett.107.215003
28. J. E. Rice, B. P. Duval, M. L. Reinke, Y. A. Podpaly, A. Bortolon, R. M. Churchill, I. Cziegler, P. H. Diamond, A. Dominguez, P. C. Ennever, C. L. Fiore, R. S. Granetz, M. J. Greenwald, A. E. Hubbard, J. W. Hughes, J. H. Irby, Y. Ma, E. S. Marmar, R. M. McDermott, M. Porkolab, N. Tsujii, and S. M. Wolfe, Nucl. Fusion
51
(8), 083005 (2011).
https://doi.org/10.1088/0029-5515/51/8/083005
Recently, rotation reversal was observed in KSTAR experiments, whereas there was no clear evidence of confinement saturations.
29
29. D. H. Na, N. Yong-Su, S. G. Lee, C. Angioni, S. M. Yang, H. S. Kim, T. S. Hahm, W. H. Ko, H. Jhang, W. J. Lee, and K. Team, Nucl. Fusion
56
(3), 036011 (2016).
https://doi.org/10.1088/0029-5515/56/3/036011
In most KSTAR ohmic discharges, the core toroidal rotation reversal beyond n
S
has not been observed in fast rotating KSTAR ohmic plasmas even though the data set contains various plasma currents and a wide range of density as shown in Fig.
2
.

FIG. 1.
Time evolution of plasma parameters including the core Ar impurity rotation and ion and electron temperature measured by XICS (shot No. 6175).

FIG. 2.
Ohmic energy confinement versus average electron density ranges for various plasma currents.

Figure
3
shows a temporal evolution of plasma parameters and profile measurements in ohmic discharge for the plasma current of 600 kA with a limited circular plasma shape (elongation is about 1.65). The toroidal rotation in Fig.
3(a)
represents a good example of the cross-calibration between the XICS and CES at 3.0 s. The blue open circle in Fig.
3(a)
indicates the CES measurement since a short beam-blip technique is successfully applied at 3.0 s. Although RMP for mode-locking is additionally applied, a reasonable mode-locking for the XICS calibration is not successful since the applied RMP current is not enough. The toroidal rotation and ion temperature profile measured by CES are shown in Fig.
3(b)
and they show typical behaviors in KSTAR ohmic discharges. The toroidal rotation at the plasma core is in the counter-current direction with a magnitude of 12 km/s and it decreases as the radial position increases, and it is dominantly in the co-current direction at the plasma edge region. Hollow rotation profiles are consistently observed with saturated ohmic confinement in other devices.
11,30–33
11. L. G. Eriksson, T. Hellsten, M. F. F. Nave, J. Brzozowski, K. Holmström, T. Johnson, J. Ongena, K. D. Zastrow, and J.-E. Contributors, Plasma Phys. Controlled Fusion
51
(4), 044008 (2009).
https://doi.org/10.1088/0741-3335/51/4/044008
30. J. S. deGrassie, K. H. Burrell, L. R. Baylor, W. Houlberg, and J. Lohr, Phys. Plasmas
11
(9), 4323 (2004).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.1778751
31. L. Porte, S. Coda, S. Alberti, G. Arnoux, P. Blanchard, A. Bortolon, A. Fasoli, T. P. Goodman, Y. Klimanov, Y. Martin, M. Maslov, A. Scarabosio, and H. Weisen, Nucl. Fusion
47
(8), 952 (2007).
https://doi.org/10.1088/0029-5515/47/8/029
32. R. M. McDermott, C. Angioni, G. D. Conway, R. Dux, E. Fable, R. Fischer, T. Pütterich, F. Ryter, E. Viezzer, and ASDEX Upgrade Team, Nucl. Fusion
54
(4), 043009 (2014).
https://doi.org/10.1088/0029-5515/54/4/043009
33. J. E. Rice, C. Gao, M. L. Reinke, P. H. Diamond, N. T. Howard, H. J. Sun, I. Cziegler, A. E. Hubbard, Y. A. Podpaly, W. L. Rowan, J. L. Terry, M. A. Chilenski, L. Delgado-Aparicio, P. C. Ennever, D. Ernst, M. J. Greenwald, J. W. Hughes, Y. Ma, E. S. Marmar, M. Porkolab, A. E. White, and S. M. Wolfe, Nucl. Fusion
53
(3), 033004 (2013).
https://doi.org/10.1088/0029-5515/53/3/033004
The spatial reversal of the rotation in the core and the edge of the plasmas may infer that the intrinsic rotation source in the core and edge regime exists separately.

FIG. 3.
(a) Time evolution of plasma parameters measured by XICS and CES. (b) Toroidal rotation and ion temperature profile measured by CES.
IV. INTRINSIC ROTATION SCALING IN KSTAR
Section:
A. Empirical scaling

The toroidal rotation scaling has a rather simple physical explanation in terms of the imbalance of the particle momentum from the neighboring drift orbits.
14,34
14. F. I. Parra, M. F. F. Nave, A. A. Schekochihin, C. Giroud, J. S. de Grassie, J. H. F. Severo, P. de Vries, and K. D. Zastrow, Phys. Rev. Lett.
108
(9), 095001 (2012).
https://doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevLett.108.095001
34. K. C. Shaing, M. S. Chu, C. T. Hsu, S. A. Sabbagh, S. Jae Chun, and Y. Sun, Plasma Phys. Controlled Fusion
54
(12), 124033 (2012).
https://doi.org/10.1088/0741-3335/54/12/124033
Based on the theory, both collisional and turbulent transport can generate the flow due to the temperature inhomogeneity. Since the plasma has an inhomogeneity of the ion and electron temperature, we extract the toroidal rotation scaling with respect to the two temperatures separately. The experimental data cover a wide range of the plasma's current from 300 kA to 800 kA, average electron density from 0.8 to 3.3 × 10
19
m
−3
, and elongation from 1.2 to 1.7 for each shot. The toroidal magnetic field is 2 T. The scaling result with ion temperature over plasma current is shown in Fig.
4
, and the linear fitting slope is −23. Each data point with a certain error bar represents each individual discharge. In the TCV tokamak, T
i
/I
P
scaling with core toroidal rotation was first observed,
16
16. A. Scarabosio, A. Bortolon, B. P. Duval, A. Karpushov, and A. Pochelon, Plasma Phys. Controlled Fusion
48
(5), 663 (2006).
https://doi.org/10.1088/0741-3335/48/5/012
and the resulting slope is −12.5. Recently, Parra
et al.
theoretically derived a similar scaling result with toroidal rotation in various devices, and the resulting slope is −18. As noted earlier, in Parra scaling, the differences of toroidal rotation and ion temperature in the core and edge are used, whereas the absolute values of toroidal rotation and ion temperature in the core are directly applied in this study. Although T
i
/I
P
scaling is independent of machine size, the resulting slopes are observed with different values. Since the scaling law was derived with a simple ordering, the stiffness of plasma temperature and current may not be properly reflected. The intrinsic error field of each device can induce rotation damping. Especially in KSTAR asymmetric magnetic fields,
δ
B
B
∼
10
−
5
, are extremely small,
22
22. Y. In, J. K. Park, J. M. Jeon, J. Kim, and M. Okabayashi, Nucl. Fusion
55
(4), 043004 (2015).
https://doi.org/10.1088/0029-5515/55/4/043004
and the rotation damping caused by NTV is predicted to be negligible compared to that of the other devices.

FIG. 4.
Toroidal rotation scaling with the ion temperature over plasma current.

The physical mechanism of T
i
/I
P
scaling is considered in two different points of view. The neoclassical theory predicts “steady state rotation” or “offset rotation” which is proportional to the ion temperature gradient and the inverse of the poloidal magnetic field as shown in Eq.
(1)
.
20
20. A. J. Cole, C. C. Hegna, and J. D. Callen, Phys. Plasmas
15
(5), 056102 (2008).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.2838241
Otherwise, the intrinsic rotation induced by micro-instabilities is expected in order of residual stress,
R.
14,35
14. F. I. Parra, M. F. F. Nave, A. A. Schekochihin, C. Giroud, J. S. de Grassie, J. H. F. Severo, P. de Vries, and K. D. Zastrow, Phys. Rev. Lett.
108
(9), 095001 (2012).
https://doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevLett.108.095001
35. K. C. Shaing, Phys. Rev. Lett.
86
(4), 640–
643
(2001).
https://doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevLett.86.640
In spite of different physical mechanism, similar qualitative scaling is obtained and consistent with experimental T
i
/I
P
scaling
V
offset
≅
−
3.5

B
θ

Since ions are predicted to be heated only by equilibrations with electrons in ohmic discharges,
36
36. B. Lloyd, P. Carolan, and C. Warrick, Plasma Phys. Controlled Fusion
38
(9), 1627 (1996).
https://doi.org/10.1088/0741-3335/38/9/007
we check a proportionality between toroidal rotation and electron temperature. It may give a hint about electron contribution on toroidal rotation. As shown in Fig.
5
, a clear linear scaling with the electron temperature over the plasma current is also observed, and the resulting slope is about −3.2. The electron temperature used in Fig.
5
is from electron cyclotron emission (ECE) which is well verified with XICS measurement.
37
37. S. H. Jeong, K. D. Lee, Y. Kogi, K. Kawahata, Y. Nagayama, A. Mase, and M. Kwon, Rev. Sci. Instrum.
81
(10), 10D922 (2010).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.3491224
The empirical scaling results may imply that both ions and electrons play an important role in determining the intrinsic toroidal rotation. The temperature ratio of T
i
/T
e
also shows a meaningful trend as shown in Fig.
6
. As the temperature ratio is increased, the core toroidal rotation is increased toward the co-current direction.

FIG. 5.
Toroidal rotation scaling with the electron temperature over plasma current.

FIG. 6.
Toroidal rotation trend of the ion to electron temperature ratio.

Note that these empirical scaling laws show consistent results for the initial current ramp-up phase. As mentioned earlier, the clear inflection point is observed during the current ramp-up phase, and Fig.
7
shows the linear scaling at this period. In this case, the T
e
/I
P
scaling in time evolution seems to be more reasonable to explain the inflection point than that of T
i
/I
P
. The time evolution characteristics will be investigated in future works.

FIG. 7.
T
i
/I
P
and T
e
/I
P
scaling during plasma current ramp-up phase.

The toroidal rotation versus stored energy divided by plasma current (W
T
/I
P
) without any confinement improvements in KSTAR ohmic discharges is shown in Fig.
8
. Interestingly, even though absolute values of toroidal rotation and plasma stored energy are utilized, the scaling result shows a positive slope similar to Rice scaling. In this respect of the correlation, extended data can be a crucial evidence of the intrinsic rotation sources for plasmas with a counter-current direction. Assuming an enhancement of confinement with this positive correlation (for example, ohmic H-mode), the toroidal rotation could change from the counter-current to the co-current direction. Since the plasma stored energy is a global parameter, it contains both ion and electron contribution. In this point of view, the core intrinsic rotation source may exist in both co- and current-current directions, and toroidal rotation depends on the background plasma parameters.

FIG. 8.
Toroidal rotation scaling with the plasma stored energy over plasma current.
B. ITER predictions

The intrinsic rotation is important because recent observations show that even a small amount of toroidal rotation could stabilize RWM and a critical rotation speed is about 0.2%–0.3% of the Alfvén speed on the q = 2 surface.
38
38. M. Takechi, G. Matsunaga, N. Aiba, T. Fujita, T. Ozeki, Y. Koide, Y. Sakamoto, G. Kurita, A. Isayama, and Y. Kamada, Phys. Rev. Lett.
98
(5), 055002 (2007).
https://doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevLett.98.055002
Table
I
shows an ITER reference scenario: a minor radius of 2 m, plasma current of 15 MA, averaged ion temperature of 8 keV, toroidal magnetic field on the magnetic axis of 5.3 T, and poloidal field of a tenth of the toroidal field. The estimated level of intrinsic rotation using the ITER reference scenario is as follows.
39
39. A. C. C. Sips, O. for the Steady State. and the Transport Physics Topical Groups of the International Tokamak Physics Activity, Plasma Phys. Controlled Fusion
47
(5A), A19 (2005).
https://doi.org/10.1088/0741-3335/47/5A/003

TABLE I.
Plasma parameter for ITER reference scenario.

Figures
9(a)
and
9(b)
show the linearly extended toroidal rotation for ITER based on the KSTAR scaling results. In this simple analysis, a limited plasma shape with a slight elongation of 1.2 is adopted to minimize any shaping effects. This scaling contains multiple data points for many KSTAR ohmic discharges. From these results, the estimated toroidal rotation in ITER is marked with a blue asterisk in Figs.
9(a)
and
9(b)
, and they correspond to 0.37 and 0.2% of the Alfvén speed, respectively. Here, the calculated Alfvén speed is 8200 km/s.

FIG. 9.
The estimated level of intrinsic rotation in ITER based on the KSTAR scaling result.
V. COMPARISONS WITH CANDIDATES
Section:
A. Neoclassical candidates

The offset rotation calculated from the neoclassical theory can be a possible candidate source of the intrinsic rotation.
12,20,40,41
12. J. Seol, S. G. Lee, B. H. Park, H. H. Lee, L. Terzolo, K. C. Shaing, K. I. You, G. S. Yun, C. C. Kim, K. D. Lee, W. H. Ko, J. G. Kwak, W. C. Kim, Y. K. Oh, J. Y. Kim, S. S. Kim, and K. Ida, Phys. Rev. Lett.

(19), 195003 (2012).
https://doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevLett.109.195003

(5), 056102 (2008).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.2838241
40. K. C. Shaing, Phys. Plasmas
10
(5), 1443 (2003).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.1567285

16
(5), 056119 (2009).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.3129164
As shown in Eq.
(1)
, the offset rotation is proportional to the ion temperature over plasma current which shows a good agreement with the experimental observations in KSTAR. The NTV torque density is shown as
12,41
12. J. Seol, S. G. Lee, B. H. Park, H. H. Lee, L. Terzolo, K. C. Shaing, K. I. You, G. S. Yun, C. C. Kim, K. D. Lee, W. H. Ko, J. G. Kwak, W. C. Kim, Y. K. Oh, J. Y. Kim, S. S. Kim, and K. Ida, Phys. Rev. Lett.

(5), 056119 (2009).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.3129164

Since the offset rotation is determined by the ion temperature profile, its magnitude can be comparable to the core rotation measurement. The NTV torque density in KSTAR is an order of 10
−7
N/m
2
since the intrinsic error field is extremely low.
22
22. Y. In, J. K. Park, J. M. Jeon, J. Kim, and M. Okabayashi, Nucl. Fusion
55
(4), 043004 (2015).
https://doi.org/10.1088/0029-5515/55/4/043004
Otherwise, external magnetic perturbations are necessary to plasma approaches to this level. From this result, the intrinsic error field is not expected to be a dominant intrinsic rotation source in KSTAR ohmic plasmas. For further comparison with neoclassical candidates, rotation induced ion orbit loss will be considered in a future study.
B. Turbulence candidates

Previous studies suggest that the intrinsic torque driven by micro-instabilities plays an important role in the formation of the toroidal rotation profile and the intrinsic torque direction is influenced by dominant turbulence modes such as trapped electron mode (TEM) and ion temperature gradient (ITG). Comparing a critical gradient for both turbulence modes is one of the typical methods to identify the dominant turbulence mode in certain profile measurements. We applied the critical gradient formula derived by Romanelli
42
42. F. Romanelli, Phys. Fluids B: Plasma Phys.
1
(5), 1018 (1989).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.859023
and Hahm and Tang

1
(6), 1185 (1989).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.859197
for one particular ohmic discharge from KSTAR (shot No. 17021) since it is applicable to standard tokamak core plasmas.

15
(4), 042310 (2008).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.2906223

The hollow rotation profile for shot No. 17021 is observed to be similar as shown in Fig.
3(b)
. Figure
10
shows the ion temperature, electron temperature, and electron density profile measured by CES, ECE, and Thomson scattering,
45
45. J. H. Lee, S. T. Oh, and H. M. Wi, Rev. Sci. Instrum.
81
(10), 10D528 (2010).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.3494275
respectively. The solid lines in Fig.
10
are fitted results with a parabolic formula. Figure
11
compares stability conditions for the critical gradient of ITG and TEM turbulence mode, and the gradient from the measured profiles shown in Fig.
10
. In the core regime, both ITG and TEM mode co-exist at 2.5 s. Since the critical gradient is derived from the local heat flux which is proportional to the local gradient and critical gradient, the difference can be used for the indirect comparison with turbulence relevant parameters such as the temperature ratio.
46
46. W. Horton, G. T. Hoang, C. Bourdelle, X. Garbet, M. Ottaviani, and L. Colas, Phys. Plasmas
11
(5), 2600 (2004).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.1690761
For the comprehensive understanding of an interaction between the modes, quasi-linear theory and nonlinear simulations will be investigated.

FIG. 10.
The measured and fitted ion temperature, electron temperature, and electron density profile for shot No. 17021.

FIG. 11.
Stability conditions of ITG and TEM turbulence mode for shot No. 17021.
VI. SUMMARY
Section:

The core intrinsic toroidal rotation behaviors without any external momentum sources utilizing carefully selected pure ohmic plasmas are investigated in KSTAR. The measured core toroidal rotation is mostly in the counter-current direction and its magnitude in the steady-state is well fitted by T
i
/I
P
scaling with a slope of about −23. The possible explanation of the well fitted T
i
/I
P
scaling is compared with NTV offset rotation and stability conditions comparing the critical gradient for ion and electron turbulence modes. In these comparisons, it is hard to identify the origin of intrinsic rotation among the possible explanations. The experimental observation only shows that the intrinsic rotation in counter-current directions is probably under the influence of the ion channel. For a comprehensive understanding of the intrinsic rotation, we will extend the scaling studies for rotation in co-current directions and investigate the remaining neoclassical and turbulence candidates in future work.

The authors would like to acknowledge the KSTAR team, and J. W. Yoo appreciates Dr. K. C. Shaing for invaluable comments. This work was supported by the Korea Ministry of Science, ICT and Future Planning under the KSTAR project contracts.
